_description: UK Government Spending by Department - 2024-25 fiscal year. Based on OBR March 2024 EFO and Spring Budget 2024 plans.
_source: OBR Economic and Fiscal Outlook March 2024; HM Treasury PESA 2024; Spring Budget 2024

_components: NHS provider spending classified as AME

dhsc.name: Department of Health and Social Care
dhsc._nhsStaff: NHS England employs ~1.4 million, making it the largest employer in Europe

capitalInvestment._backlogNote: Total estimated maintenance backlog: £11.6bn. Annual capital insufficient to prevent backlog growing.

pressures: 7.6m elective waiting list (July 2024)
112,000 staff vacancies across NHS England
£11.6bn maintenance backlog
Agency spending ~£10bn/year displacing permanent recruitment
Social care interface: delayed discharges costing ~£2bn/year in NHS beds
Mental health referrals up ~30% post-COVID
GP access crisis: average 2+ weeks for routine appointment

realGrowthHistory._note: COVID years distort 2020-2024 average. Underlying trend ~2.5% post-2022.

education.name: Department for Education

schools._perPupilNote: Real-terms per-pupil funding in 2024-25 was approximately at 2010 levels after a decade of erosion

capitalProgrammes._note: RAAC concrete crisis (2023) revealed decades of underinvestment in school buildings

pressures: SEND deficit: cumulative local authority SEND deficits exceeding £4bn nationally
Teacher recruitment crisis: secondary school targets missed for 9 consecutive years
Teacher retention: ~33,000 leaving per year, especially in STEM and early career
Real-terms per-pupil funding eroded ~9% 2010-2020 before partial recovery
Early years: childcare expansion (phased from April 2024) costs £4-5bn when fully rolled out
School buildings: ~700,000 pupils in schools with major condition needs

mod.name: Ministry of Defence

keySpendingAreas._note: Equipment plan has an unfunded gap estimated at £7-17bn over 10 years (NAO)

pressures: Ukraine: ongoing military aid commitment (~£2.5bn/year)
Equipment plan affordability gap: £7-17bn (NAO)
Recruitment and retention crisis: Army ~7% below strength target
Nuclear deterrent renewal (Dreadnought submarines): costs escalating
Pressure to reach 2.5% GDP (additional ~£14bn/year from current level)
Ammunition stocks depleted by Ukraine donations need replenishment

homeOffice.name: Home Office
pressures: Asylum backlog: ~175,000 cases pending decision (July 2024)
Rwanda scheme costs (pre-cancellation by Labour): ~£290m already spent
Hotel accommodation for asylum seekers: ~£8m/day
Police officer numbers: recovering from 21,000 cut during austerity
Organised crime (NCA) funding inadequate for growing threats
Counter-terrorism: evolving threat landscape post-Hamas/Israel

moj.name: Ministry of Justice
pressures: Prison population at record ~88,000 (capacity ~88,900): system at breaking point
Crown Court backlog: ~67,000 cases (tripled since 2019)
258 courts closed during austerity, remaining courts crumbling
Legal aid funding still ~30% below 2010 levels in real terms
Prison building programme behind schedule
Probation service struggling after botched privatisation and renationalisation

dwp.name: Department for Work and Pensions
dwp._ameSpending: Most DWP spending is AME (benefits). DEL covers administration only.

statePension._note: Triple lock: rises by highest of CPI, earnings growth, or 2.5%. Cost ~£130bn/year. Single biggest item of public spending.

pressures: State pension triple lock: costs growing ~£3-5bn/year above inflation
Disability benefits rising rapidly: PIP caseload growing ~5% per year
Post-COVID economic inactivity: 2.8m long-term sick (up from 2.0m pre-COVID)
Universal Credit: ~6 million claimants, system under strain
Cost of living pressures still driving increased claims
Fraud and error in benefits estimated at ~£8.3bn/year

hmTreasury.name: HM Treasury
hmTreasury._note: Tiny departmental budget but controls all other departments' spending. Houses the fiscal policy-making function.

transport.name: Department for Transport

keySpendingAreas._hs2Note: HS2 Phase 1 (London-Birmingham) proceeding. Phase 2 (to Manchester) cancelled October 2023. Estimated total cost £60-70bn for Phase 1 alone.

pressures: HS2 cost escalation: Phase 1 now estimated at £60-70bn
Rail franchising model effectively nationalised post-COVID (GBR creation delayed)
Road maintenance backlog estimated at £12bn+
Northern Powerhouse Rail cancelled alongside HS2 Phase 2
Electric vehicle infrastructure investment needs
Bus services declining in rural and suburban areas

dluhc_mhclg.name: Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
pressures: Local authority funding crisis: 7 councils have effectively declared bankruptcy (s114 notices)
Building safety remediation post-Grenfell: estimated £15-50bn total cost
Housing targets: 1.5m homes over parliament (300,000/year) vs ~220,000 delivered
Homelessness: 100,000+ in temporary accommodation
Council tax system based on 1991 valuations, deeply outdated

defra.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

keySpendingAreas._note: Post-Brexit: transitioning from EU Common Agricultural Policy to Environmental Land Management (ELM) scheme

pressures: Agricultural transition: farmers facing income uncertainty as BPS payments phased out
Flood risk: climate change increasing severe flooding frequency
Water quality: sewage discharge crisis requires infrastructure investment
Biodiversity decline accelerating despite commitments
Food security concerns post-Brexit and post-Ukraine

dsit.name: Department for Science, Innovation and Technology

keySpendingAreas._note: UK R&D spending target: 2.4% of GDP by 2027 (currently ~1.7% public+private). Government target is for public R&D spending of £20bn/year by 2024-25.

dcms.name: Department for Culture, Media and Sport

fcdo.name: Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office

keySpendingAreas._odaNote: ODA currently at ~0.5% of GNI (cut from 0.7% target in 2021 to fund post-COVID pressures). Restoring to 0.7% would cost additional ~£6bn/year.

pressures: ODA cut from 0.7% to 0.5% GNI: reduced development programmes globally
Ukraine aid commitments
China strategy and Indo-Pacific tilt requiring diplomatic resource reallocation
British Council: funding squeezed, closures
Pressure to restore 0.7% ODA target (costs ~£6bn/year)

desnz.name: Department for Energy Security and Net Zero

keySpendingAreas._note: Does not include energy price guarantee costs (AME, was ~£40bn in 2022-23)

greatBritishEnergy._overParliament: Phased over parliament. Publicly-owned clean energy company.

cabinetOffice.name: Cabinet Office
cabinetOffice._note: Houses the civil service reform agenda, government digital services, procurement, and political coordination.

hmrc.name: HM Revenue and Customs
hmrc._note: HMRC collects ~£848bn in tax revenues. Every £1 invested in HMRC compliance typically returns £5-18 in additional revenue.

taxGapEstimate._note: The tax gap represents the difference between tax owed and tax collected. Largest components: VAT (£7.6bn), income tax/NI/CGT (£6.4bn), corporation tax (£5.9bn).

localGovernment._description: Aggregate local government spending in England (councils, combined authorities)
pressures: 7 councils have issued Section 114 notices (effective bankruptcy declarations) since 2020
Real-terms central funding per dwelling cut ~29% from 2010-2020
Adult social care costs rising ~5% per year, unfunded
Children's social care costs rising ~10% per year
Temporary accommodation costs for homelessness spiralling
Infrastructure maintenance backlog: roads, buildings, IT systems
Council tax referendum cap limits revenue growth to ~5% per year

devolvedAdministrations._description: Block grants to devolved governments via the Barnett formula

scotland._barnettNote: Scotland receives ~20% more per capita than England through Barnett. Has devolved tax powers (Scottish Rate of IT, LBTT, etc.)

wales._note: Wales receives ~15% more per capita than England. Limited tax-varying powers.

northernIreland._note: NI receives ~25% more per capita than England. Stormont collapsed 2022-2024, adding to governance challenges.

barnettFormula._description: The Barnett formula determines changes in devolved block grants based on changes in comparable English spending
barnettFormula.mechanism: If English departmental spending changes by £X, devolved admins receive population-proportion * £X
barnettFormula.convergenceEffect: Slowly converges per-capita spending towards English levels over time (but very slowly)
barnettFormula.criticism: Does not reflect actual spending needs. Favours Scotland over Wales despite Wales having greater deprivation.

debtInterest._note: Debt interest has tripled from ~£30bn (2020-21) due to higher interest rates and index-linked gilts repricing with inflation.

sensitivity._unit: GBP billions additional debt interest per 1pp rise in Bank Rate sustained for a year
sensitivity._note: Due to high proportion of index-linked and floating-rate debt. About 25% of gilt stock is index-linked.

debtInterest._revenueNote: Debt interest consumes ~8% of all government revenue -- higher than total education spending. Before rate rises it was ~3%.

spendingRules._description: Key spending control mechanisms in UK public finance
spendingRules.spendingReviewCycle: Multi-year (typically 3 years) setting departmental DEL totals
spendingRules.currentReviewPeriod: 2022-23 to 2024-25 (set by Sunak/Hunt). Reeves announced new multi-year review for 2025-26 to 2027-28.

fiscalDragOnSpending._description: Unless spending plans are explicitly increased, real per-capita spending falls as population grows and inflation erodes nominal budgets

impliedAusterityInPlans._unit: Percent per year real terms after protecting NHS and defence
impliedAusterityInPlans._note: IFS described existing Spring 2024 spending plans as 'not credible' given service pressures. This implies cuts to justice, local government, home office, HMRC, DEFRA, and others that are politically very difficult.

nhsSpending1bn._note: NHS spending has the highest political return

defenceSpending1bn._note: Politically less visible but internationally significant

infrastructureSpending1bn._note: Highest GDP multiplier but low immediate political return

benefitSpending1bn._note: High multiplier (recipients spend immediately) but politically unpopular with median voter

departmentProtection._description: Which departments are politically 'protected' from cuts
departmentProtection._note: Cutting a 'hard protected' department carries 3-5x the approval cost of cutting an 'unprotected' one
